posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

The Flood was based on a local flood in the Persian Gulf that occurred around 3000 BCE which swallowed up the coasts. A local farmer managed to survive the flood by building a small bowl-shaped boat with a small hut inside (I would post a pic but I can't find it I keep getting Christfag shit when I search for it), brought some of his animals and rode out the storm. The bible is like many books of myth and legend: parts of them probably have some basis in truth, but until you find something that collaborates it, there is often little reason to take it super seriously, just like the Iliad is not a very accurate portrayal of whatever military action took place in Asia minor at the end of the bronze age. People totally discounted it for a long time, until an actual city was found, and now they take it slightly more seriously but with some major caveats. The bible is a super important source on the Levant for a long period of time, but it is not more reliable than contemporaneous records kept in places like Egypt or Mesopotamia. You find some clue that some small part of the bible might have some basis in real events and act like that proves the whole thing.

That's the difficulty Atheists have. The Trojan War is real, it happened, and Homer's Iliad tells of the Trojan War in between all his poetical fiction and moral allegory.

Homer's Iliad is an epic, that's it's genre, but the genres in the Bible are much more numerous. The stories are written in different styles, by different peoples, at different times. Although that isn't to say that the Bible explicitly contains any outright fiction. But when Jesus says he is the vine, he doesn't mean he is literally a plant. So one must read the Bible and understand there is a literal sense, an allegorical sense, a tropological sense and an anagogical sense.

Reading the Iliad is like looking through a stained glass window to see the thing behind it. The thing exists, but the thing isn't actually purple, and green, and orange, and blue like the stained glass is. The glass being the author, the literary devices used, the biases inherent in the person writing the thing. Reading the Bible is like looking through a hundred stained glass windows to see what's behind it.

When an Atheist peers into the window, he gets angry because he remembers his religious mother liked stained glass windows and he internally resents her and looks away from the window in spite, then a historian tells him that the thing behind the window is real, and he gets even more mad.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14605117
>Or Westeros' historiography is in a truly abysmal state and most of that world's known history is a complete fabrication
Compare this to Scandinavia history.
Because the Norse didn't write anything down before Christian conversation, we don't know anything about pre-Christian kings of Denmark, Sweden, and Norway. Only sources come from sagas that contradict each other and were written down only after three centuries after the conversion.
Take Harald Fairhair for instance, his historicity has been brought into question, because there is no solid evidence he ever existed, and many historians think he is a proto-type to justify the reign of the first Christian king of Denmark, Harald Bluetooth.
Then you have insane people like 12/13th century Saxo Grammaticus who fabricated the entire Danish line of kings predating the birth of Jesus (see Gasta Danorum).

Is it really a stretch to assume that some North had Saxo Grammaticus of their own who fabricated a bullshit line of kings for the Starks and it was accepted as factual?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14610752
>what state was pre-fall Adam in then?
Human nature was ordered properly pre-fall, . This right ordering involved the reason being subject to God, and the body to reason. This right-ordering was not ‘from nature,’ otherwise it would have remained after sin. In particular, the subjection of the reason to God was the result of a ‘supernatural endowment of grace’ according to Aquinas (aka original justice). [There is considerable debate as to the nature of the exact link between grace and original justice. What is clear, however, is that there *is* a link between the two; without grace there is no original justice.]

The fall of Adam and Eve means that human persons are born into a state of original sin rather than a state of original justice. A state of original sin is one which lacks grace. A result of a person lacking grace is that his nature is not properly ordered towards God.

>he lived in God's presence, and was, like all of us, made in His image
"To be made in the image of God is to be rational, capable of knowing and loving. But that does not entail that man by nature is ordered to the Beatific Vision, which is God’s own vision of Himself. Otherwise, God could never create any rational creature. To be rational would simply mean to be God. But God has created rational creatures, and these creatures are not Himself. They are ordered by nature to a natural end, but ordered by God’s gracious condescension and infinitely generous invitation to the supernatural end of the Beatific Vision, i.e. sharing in God’s own internal Eternal Life."
Source: https://www.calledtocommunion.com/2011/10/protestant-objections-to-the-catholic-doctrines-of-original-justice-and-original-sin

>It seems that in the early centuries of Christianity no distinctive dress was adopted by ecclesiastics. Many indications point to this conclusion ... "If any man", says [the Council of Gangra (340)], "uses the pallium [cloak] upon account of an ascetic life, and, as if there be some holiness in that, condemns those who with reverence use the birrus and other garments that are commonly worn, let him be anathema" (Hefele-Leclercq, "Hist. des Conc.", I, 1037). At the other extremity of Christendom the documents that survive concerning St. Patrick and other early Celtic bishops present them to us as habitually dressed in the casula (chasuble), which was at that time not a distinctively liturgical attire, but simply an outer garment commonly worn by the humbler classes.

>The notion that Luke painted an icon of Mary, scholars relate, first appeared during the Iconoclast controversy in the 8th century, created by those favoring icon veneration. The earliest mention of icons painted by Luke is found in a work called On the Veneration of Holy Images by Andrew of Crete, who died in the first half of the 8th century — an iconophile writing at the beginning of the Iconoclastic controversy. An oft-quoted and supposedly earlier mention in the history by 6th century writer Theodore Anagnostes of an icon painted by Luke and sent from Jerusalem to Pulcheria (Byzantine Empress: died 453) is found in 13th-century manuscripts of the history. But it is absent in earlier manuscripts from the early 11th century. That is a very strong indication that this story of a Marian icon painted by Luke was added much later to the original text. In a very well-researched book — Icons and Power: the Mother of God in Byzantium (Pennsylvania State University, 2006), Bessera V. Pentcheva writes: “The myth was invented in order to support the legitimacy of icon veneration during the Iconoclast controversy [8th and 9th centuries]. By claiming the existence of a portrait of the Theotokos painted during her lifetime by the evangelist Luke, the perpetrators of this fiction fabricated evidence for the apostolic origins and divine approval of Images.”

I was wondering the other day why the ancient Greeks stopped using their letter Digamma grammatically, reserving it for maths only.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Sound shifts are common in linguistic history, I don't know why they happened, but they did. For instance, Middle English had the great vowel shift, which is responsible for a lot of our spelling/pronunciation mismatches. Or there's Grimm's Law in the Germanic languages, where a bunch of consonants changed compared to cognates elsewhere in Indo-European.
I imagine something similar happened in ancient greek and whatever sound Digamma represented just fell out of use.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14610911
it is very confusing to me, especially because the same symbol is retained for use not only in maths but is also used as the final Sigma at the end of particular words.

does the final Sigma have a different pronounciation than the regular Sigma, or is it a matter of convenience since they didn't use punctuation?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14610852
Bear in mind that sound changes like this don't happen overnight, and it can be hard to notice they're happening. The change starts in a dialect, usually specific to a particular region or social class. By definition the change is seen as non-standard or incorrect. Then it spreads to nearby regions and keeps spreading until it becomes the standard form of the language. Think, for example, of how in British English it's common to glottalise the 't' sound in certain positions such as in the word 'hate'. This is perceived as a low-class or informal way of speaking, and yet it seems to be getting more common, to the extent that in the future it may be perceived as the standard way of speaking.

Regarding digamma in particular, I believe I read somewhere that by the time the Greek alphabet was developed, the digamma sound had already been lost in most dialects and only remained in one dialect, possibly Ionic?

>The first time Nixon and Kennedy debated was not in 1960, in fact it was on April 1, 1947 when the two new Congressmen debated in McKeesport, Pennsylvania before an audience of 150. The two were invited there to speak by 18th District Congressman John Kunkel and debate on Taft-Hartley. The debate lasted three hours and Nixon remembered it as very friendly and cordial. He thought he got the better of it because the audience at the debate was mostly local business owners (ie. Republicans) rather than blue collar workers. Nixon and Kennedy then took a train back to Washington DC, where the two were bunkmates in a sleeping car, the former on the bottom berth and the latter the top.

>Although the two were never intimates, they were on quite amicable terms with each other until the bitter animosity of the '60 presidential campaign. Kennedy sent Nixon two books as presents, a few friendly notes, and Nixon was invited to Kennedy's wedding with Jacqueline Bouvier in 1953. When Nixon set off for his Congressional fact-finding trip to Europe in August 1947, Kennedy thought he might enjoy some nookie on the trip. He gave Nixon the phone numbers of three suitable young ladies in Paris, including his own sister Patricia. According to Nixon's secretary Rosemary Woods, "Dick was so mortified at this suggestion that I think he just took the paper with the phone numbers written on it and threw it away."

The Roman Emperor Valentinian I (r. 364-375) had the most Roman death in history.

He was conducting military campaigns past the Danube and had been pillaging lands of a Germanic tribe called the Qadi. He had met with some of their chiefs and elders, and negotiated an agreement where they would provide some tribute and men to serve in the Roman army, in return for ceasing to raid Roman territory. After everything was sealed and the Qadi chiefs were basically on their way out the door, they informed the Emperor that according to their custom that while the chiefs would not lead any raids, independent warbands would still be free to ignore that directive if they chose. Additionally they said that the presence of Roman fortifications in their lands were the real source of the problem anyway.

Hearing this bombshell so enraged the Emperor that he screamed at them for so long and so hard that he burst a blood vessel in his brain and died that very day. Imagine getting so mad at Germans that you die.

posts.com: Convince me that Germany did nothing wrong in WWI. I've seen a lot of conspiracy theories to the effect that Britain tricked them into starting the war but it all sounds like schizo shit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14607805
It's not that Britain purposefully intentionally orchestrated the conditions of the war although there's an agreement that they did so unintentionally. Nevertheless, the topic of Britain's opposition to Germany predominantly comes from two avenues. Britain entered the war not out of outrage concerning Belgian neutrality in spite of that being the official story used to rev up the public. Oone needs to only look at how the Entente violated Greek neutrality during the war to see the hypocrisy of such a sentiment and if that isn't enough, one only needs to examine the illegality of Britain's blockade of German. Rather, Britain's prime reason for joining the war was to prevent the fall of France as a major power owing to British balance of power politics. If it wasn't Belgium, Britain would have construed another Casus Belli in response to German actions such as if Germany's High Seas Fleet bombarded the northern French coast. The primary benefit Britain got out of defeating Germany - which speaks to the second reason they had for entering the war - was usurping an economic rival. I won't go into the statistics now but Lloyd George outright announced his glee at the German merchant marine having been torn from them.

All in all, I wouldn't focus predominately on condemning Britain but Russia when creating a defense of Germany's actions. There was an understandable need for Germany to back Austria-Hungary whose aims for the Balkans were fundamentally conservative, despite Hotzendorff's warmongering behind the scenes, in contrast to Russia which wanted to shake up the Balkan status quo so as to further their influence and bring themselves ever closer to taking the Turkish straights. Russia was mentioning their designs on Turkey before the Turks even joined the war showing that the Balkan troubles of the early 20th Century were the result of Russia's century-long quest to gain power in the Black and Mediterranean Seas.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14607927
It also must be stated that while some in the German military did want a preventive, others, such as the Kaiser, were looking only for a localized conflict in the Balkans - perhaps merely an occupation of Belgrade to force Serbia to comply with Austrian terms. The Kaiser even gave his Chief of Staff, Von Moltke, a stroke by delaying the invasion of Luxembourg after the British dishonestly implied there was a possibility that they and France might practice neutrality. The fact that Russia began mobilizing first in secret, in contrast to Germany, showcases a desire to use said mobilization to foremostly prepare for conflict rather than forcing opposing powers to back down. Russian support was also instrumental in encouraging Serbia to take a more belligerent stance in response to the Austrian demands with the idea that they wholeheartedly conceded to most Austrian points being a myth which resulted from the clever usage of diplomatic doublespeak. See the attached excerpt from Christopher Clark's The Sleepwalkers to gain a better understanding of the nature of Serbia's response to the Austrian ultimatum. Still, some blame does go on Austria given they had no faith that Serbia would comply to their satisfaction but the nature of the Serbian response seems to justify that belief. As it pertains to how Russia impacted the Serbian response, Serbian diplomats in Saint Petersburg sent back multiple telegrams proclaiming that Serbia had been promised Russian military support alongside a telegram hinting at Russia's secret mobilization prior to the drafting of Serbia's reply. After being informed of Russia's position through their envoy, more and more Serbs were outright hoping for an Austrian invasion, even talking with glee at the thought, which once again goes to show how Russian encouragement intensified the crisis.

It was only after the bad faith of British diplomacy became clear that the Kaiser consented to allow for the army's plans for waging war with France to proceed. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14607805
Also, in terms of Submarine Warfare, the Kaiser was personally opposed to it - especially the unrestricted variant of it - but both German militarists and the German public became increasingly in favor of it and allowing the submarines operational freedom as a result of the effects that the British blockade had on the German strategic situation and the welfare of the average German person creating both a need to break it and a desire to get back at Britain, so to speak. Unrestricted Submarine Warfare came back into usage despite Germany initially dialing back on such policies after the Lusitania as officials in the German military were also growing increasingly desperate on finding a way to end the war with the maritime powers. Faulty statistics that overestimated the effects of an Unrestricted Submarine Campaign led Germany to believe they could perhaps strangle Britain's resources and force the nation to come to terms before either an American entry or the transport of American troops to Europe. They also underestimated the amount of forces the United States would bring to Europe in the event of a potential American entrance in response to a revitalized Unrestricted Submarine Warfare campaign.

German attempts to adhere to Prize Law in the past allowed for the British to easily circumvent German efforts and take advantage of the strict rules of engagement by arming merchant ships so that they could attack U-Boats upon surfacing or ordering them to ram U-Boats in the same circumstances.

So, while restarting Unrestricted Submarine Warfare was a mistake - the rationale behind it is nevertheless still understandable. It wasn't an act of evil but desperation that led Germany to reinitiate the policy.

>>14609070
>Choose Russia over Austria
This is very wrong.

Germany's ultimate geopolitical goal was to weaken Russia and with the benefit of hindsight we can say definitively this thinking was correct. Paving the path for the dissolution of Austria-Hungary (the natural consequence of allying Russia) would massively strengthen Russia's position and after an inevitable Austrian breakup, Germany would be forced to take up the responsibility of protecting the Balkans from Russian influence--a contest they could not win. Germany would see itself become the junior partner in the alliance.

The correct option for Germany is an alliance with Britain, which the British would have been very open to had Wilhelm been a competent statesman. Austria-Hungary could be left isolated only to return to the German sphere as a junior partner to Germany. Under such a set of alliances peace would likely be preserved until the absolutist, anti-reformist Russian regime would eventually collapse due to growing domestic discontent and international isolation. At that point Germany and Britain could move to secure a network of free eastern European democracies across the collapsing Russian empire.

With Russia out of the picture, the cannibalization of Austria-Hungary could take effect. Germany could annex Austria proper and make new free states out of the rest. Britain would naturally be concerned about Germany's now superior industrial power, but this fear would be washed over as the British empire would be unquestionably unchallengeable. Germany could not expand her borders on the continent and would have to play second fiddle to the British when it came to colonial affairs, a fair balance of power that both Germany and Britain would be comfortable with.

The other option is to, of course, keep Willy's shitty geopolitical ideas and just win the war.

>Cortés could be brutal—no gentle soldier in that age could have long survived—yet he instinctively preferred to avoid bloodshed whenever possible. >He needed no special rationale to seek out hidden kingdoms; no Spaniard or European of that time did. It was enough that the world was suddenly open to them. >>14607597
It's a bunch of reasons, some of them are being mentioned in this thread. But China was never really "restored" after Qin Shi Huang, per se. The various dynasties were all different from each other, from different regions and cultures and formed a kingdom to encompass the region of "China". What happened was that basically over time the Mandate became the driving force behind wanting to acquire Chinese territory, not the belief that this territory is a nation to be formed.

Rome couldn't be formed for two reasons:
1. The full extent of the territories was never recovered, thus nobody who claimed to be the Roman Emperor had any legitimacy and was dismissed since everyone wanted to be the Roman Emperor and every king in Europe tried to derive his legitimacy from Rome.
2. Rome conquered various civilizations that had already well established cultures of their and amny of them even had thousand of years of history. You can't just erase that. In contrast to China whose conquests were mainly of civilizations that were in their early stages and didn't have a coherent identity yet.

BUT there is a modern misconception that the Chinese "dynasties" were the same country. The citizens of the various dynasties and kingdoms never referred themselves as Chinese or even considered the previous dynastic incarnations as part of the current dynasty. The concept of China came during the Qing and more specifically - after its fall and the formation of the Republic of China.

It's like saying the Frankish Empire was a dynasty of the Roman Empire because Charlemagne claimed the title of Roman Emperor.

Numerous factors. You should read "Escape from Rome" for a detailed answer.

Gyst of it is that the Chinese were a lot more established as a single identity, so during some civil war you would not be the "King of X People", you'd just be a warlord. There was a cultural impetus to get shit back together.

Geography also played a role, with much of China Proper being plains as opposed to the very geographically diverse Western Europe, so it was simply harder to unite.

The conquerors of Europe were also much more infantry based than Steppe Nomad #328. That lock of mobility made them want to bottle up in their own littles forts until like every fucking village had a castle with its own little mini-warlord. They also had a different inheritance system than the Steppe nomads who invaded China, dividing lands by sons instead of all the sons murdering each other for the land.

The state ideology of Europe was forcibly changed to various Christianities which made the idea of a unified continuity back to Rome pointless. No one wanted to restore the sacred hearth of Vesta, and the Roman State was the apparatus around fueling and protecting the sacred hearth of Vesta. There was zero political or cultural legitimacy tracing back to Rome.

Compare that with China which has a (theoretical) 3,000 year long religious continuity. The CCP sponsors rituals that were, again theoretically, performed by the Son of Heaven 3,000 years ago. Likewise, there is, and has always been, massive political and cultural legitimacy in tracing back to the, as far as the Chinese are concerned, literal creation of meaning and culture itself by the ancient Sage Kings.

For most of the Medeival period Europeans were far more concerned with creating imagined genealogies and lineages tracing themselves back to this ancient Jew or that ancient Jew rather than confirming descent from Julius Caesar or whatever. It wasn't even until around the time of the Renaissance that nobility started creating descent from characters in Homer (even Snorri Sturluson does this lmfao), and even then that was just mere affectation. People gained and lost power by virtue of their descent from Confucius. People TODAY have political positions because of their descent from Confucius.

I'm just going to repeat myself to make a point: The dominant religious distinction in the West is whether you use the Liturgy invented in the 1970s or in the 1870s. In China, it's whether you use the ones from 1,000BC, or 900BC.

>>14607597
Its a heavily debated question, but one interesting thing I've seen sinologists argue is that China's unified logographic written system may have been a factor in facilitating reunification.

One of the first emperor's most enduring contributions was creating a unified writing system to replace local variations (and in typical fashion, killing anyone who didn't use it). The Chinese have a logographic writing system, quite different from our syllabic one. In syllabic writing systems each character represents a different sound, which are pieced together to approximate the sound of the word when spoken. The Chinese don't do that. Every character in Chinese represents a different word. There are clues in the glyph, where similar concepts will have a similar "core", but you still need to learn thousands of characters if you want to be literate. This seems tedious and inefficient compared to our system, and it is, but it does have one advantage that might not be immediately obvious.

If you and I both speak different languages, but can read Chinese then we will be able to communicate. No matter what language you speak you'll always use the same glyphs to express them, because the glyphs represent the words rather than how they're pronounced.

So, it's been argued, that was a key unifying factor that made it easier to keep China's massive and disparate groups united into a cohesive bloc.

>>14607597
The Western Roman Empire was not culturally diverse at all and most people thought of themselves exclusively as Romans. Hell modern China proper is more diverse in accent and dialect than the Western Empire ever was. The problem faced in recreating the Roman State in the West was that there wasn't any state with the resources to accomplish that and no forces pushing for the creation of a monopolistic state. The Roman Republic was able to rise due to extreme conditions within their society, namely extremely high rates of mobilisation (as in, 20% of men across all of Central Italy were actively involved in military campaigns, at all times. During the Punic wars this rose to some 30-40%) and the social imperative to go to war. Any state in the Middle Ages would have been lucky to even get a tenth of these rates for campaign, let alone sustain it indefinitely. It would be like Edward III running around with armies of a total of 500,000 men at all times.

There was nothing in Western Europe that promoted the creation of large states, unlike the Middle East and China which were almost always ruled by a monopolistic state as the norm with the end of collapse of one being the exception. Large external pressure from nomads promoted central power and the formation of larger states, in Western Europe this happened with England and the Viking invasions. While the Carolingian Empire collapsed and massively decentralized, the Kings of Wessex were able to increase their central power as increasing pressure allowed them to get away with more for the sake of their survival.

>Having ruled more or less unchallenged as leader of Yugoslavia from 1945 until his death on May 4 1980, Tito had accrued the kind of personality cult that other East European leaders could only dream of. It was a cult that extended beyond the grave.

posts.com: >Tito’s popularity with young people was genuine and widespread (although far from universal), and it left a significant mark on popular culture. One of the most popular rock-pop songs of the early Eighties was Count on Us (Računajte na nas) by Novi Sad band Rani Mraz, released in 1979 and much quoted during and after his final illness. “Some may think we are carried by the wrong flow/Because we listen to records and play rock and roll” (Sumnjaju neki da nosi nas pogrešan tok/Jer slušamo ploče i sviramo rok) went the refrain, driving home the message that electric guitars and denim jeans were by no means incompatible with Titoist idealism. The song was written by Đorđe Balašević, who went on to become an “urban chansonnier” (his own words) of great poetic subtlety, delivering social criticism as well as wistful balladeering. Another song that served as soundtrack to the immediate post-Tito years was Comrade Tito We Pledge Ourselves to You (Druže Tito mi ti se kunemo), a song which had its origins in the Partisan period but which became a radio hit when covered by pop heartthrob Zdravko Čolić in 1977. Re-released in spring 1980 when Tito was already in hospital, it went on to sell over 300,000 copies.

>Laibach was formed in 1980 shortly after the death of Marshal Josip Broz Tito, the Yugoslavian post-war leader who had spent his political career establishing the principles of non-alignment within the 3rd, 2nd and 1st world and especially within communism. His death initiated a period of uncertainty in Yugoslavia, resulting in power struggles between conservative nationalist hard-liners and more liberal politicians; a period, which saw struggles and disagreements between the different republics constituting Yugoslavia. Laibach’s response to this confusion was to present their group as a totalitarian organization whose zeal for authority far outstripped that of the state. They announced their formation and activities through poster campaigns around the Slovene cities of Trbovlje and Ljubljana, utilizing elements of National Socialism and Socialist Realism propaganda imagery coupled with partisan folk art to create a startling effect.

[...]

>Dressed in stark black and grey (mainly Yugoslav army) uniforms, Laibach performed ferocious noise assaults before a backdrop of totalitarian regalia and wartime slides with political speeches from Tito, Jaruzelski, Mussolini, and others spliced into the mix. Playing in front of aggressive hostile crowds was not without its risks as lead singer Tomaž Hostnik discovered after a bottle struck him during the show. Although bleeding from a facial wound he showed no reaction and the photograph of the wounded Hostnik is now one of the most iconic Laibach images. Unfortunately, Hostnik never performed to more appreciative audiences as in December 1982 he took his own life.

I don't think you understand why the brain size/body mass ratio matters.
It's not that best ratio = best brain, but rather that a worse ratio implies a lot less of the brain will be put to any intellectual use. The more body mass you have, the more brain mass you need just to control your body. The reason why these massive mammals have huge brains but aren't as smart as us is that most of that brain mass is used to control the body and track its movement in 3d space.
None of this obviously implies that we should be dumber than ants. Brains aren't magic, there's a limit to how complex a mind can be based on the total number of neurons. The ants may use theirs effectively, but they don't have a lot.

>>14610500
Pretty much all agrarian-to-industrial transitions are painful. We pretty much have to include the American Civil War as part of the transition, which by today's equivalent population would be seven million deaths or something like that, and that was relatively easy. More often, industrializing involves literally uprooting your entire socioeconomic structure and replacing it with one that runs on entirely different principles, so there's no way that it isn't messy as all hell at best. The other problem is that your options are basically to either go through all that shit or eventually get crushed by someone else who did industrialize.

You can avoid the worst of it though if you have reliable trading partners who can reliably supply you with food and agricultural machinery -- in bulk, and hopefully with fuel.

The Soviets had the absolute worst of it to deal with, with China not being in a great position either. Yugoslavia handled it a lot better, not because the socialists there were magically smarter, but because the conditions for dealing with the issue were already partly in place. (Yugoslavia was semi-industrialized already -- sure, the Nazis blew up most of it, but the pre-existing logistics, institutional knowledge, and machinery existed already.)

Plus let's not romanticize pre-industrial Russian or Chinese agrarian living conditions. It wasn't exactly like those YouTube videos young attractive women make nowadays about country village living or whatever. It's more like "praying your kids don't die from a random fever" and going from that to living reasonably comfortable lives within a few years, where there are hospitals so your kids don't have to die, you have electricity now, or even a roof over your head when you didn't have one before. But to get there, you have to fight several wars led by ferocious enemies who are determined to stop that from happening.

>>14608783
You're pretty much asking the same question that social psychologists asked post-WWII. The Robber's Cave study, Asch conformity experiments, Milgram shock tests, all of these were the basis of what eventually became Deindividuation Theory. Essentially the ideas got summed up into what Zimbardo "tested" in the prison study, the idea that being part of a group means a weakening/loss of inhibition and pressure to continually one-up each other demonstrating commitment to the group. As you can imagine, that can lead to some fucked up shit.

But it's important to point out that these early theories were only half right. BBC has a redo of the Prison experiment run in part by one of the researchers who demonstrated the limits of deindividuation theory, his basic idea was that these effects go both ways. If you can get people to act in horrific ways while they're acting the part of "soldier" you should also be able to get the opposite effect if they think they're part of something prosocial. And they do! For example, if you dress people up in nurse costumes before doing the shock tests, they are significantly less willing to hurt other people. The general consensus today is the SIDE model, essentially something that takes the lessons of early Deindividuation theory and reconciles them with a more context-based approach.

The mistake is to think these effects are bound up in specific ideologies or arguments, they aren't. You can get deindividuation effects, good and bad, from completely arbitrary things like what artist people prefer, colors, and coinflips. What matters about an ideology/crowd is what the established norms for it are. So if you have a norm of killing the other guys, like most militaries do, it can drift into killing indiscriminately.

Basically, in very broad terms, slippery slopes are real in this context. You start by killing only your political opponents and eventually you're digging mass graves.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14610365

Regardless of metallurgy, the semi-automatic handgun requires smokeless powder - there is no way you can get black powder to work instead, both for reliability of the weapon and for the primer itself. Smokeless powder requires pure nitric acid, which can theoretically be produced on a small scale with 18th-century equipment. But it wasn't available in real usable quantities until the late 19th century, when electric power was finally available (and thus this is also when the first semi-automatic handguns were invented).

So there really isn't anyway you could reverse engineer a Glock in ancient times. The absolute earliest is probably mid-18th century. Note if you can produce nitric acid, you can also make TNT, which is far more militarily useful anyway.

One hundred fifty are besieged by five thousand;
Not only the provisions but the ammunition is all gone.
Thirty-two men hear the news and hurry to the scene.
The heavy strokes of their sabers lead them into the fortress, through the ranks of the enemy to see
The commander of the fortress wet with blood,
And his men reeling against the walls with exhaustion but with swords in hand.
Now comes the dauntless South Carolinian,
Knowing that if he does not answer duty's call, disgrace and shame will be his.
Returning he rides into the siege on a white charger,
Salutes the besieged with a smile, and says, "We die together."
They bind up their wounds and fight in higher spirits.
Speak not of the bravery of Chang Hsun at Suiyang, for here the one hundred and eighty-two corpses were laid; not one surrendered.
The people of the twenty-four states get inspiration thereby,
And learn for the first time that unanimous cooperation is superior to geographical advantage.
Why should they be mourned? For the dauntless, it is not a pain but a pleasure to cover an obstruction miles long.
Lo! the mouth of the river once occupied by the enemy is in the possession of the T' ang!
Now I am on a journey, far away from my home across the ocean.
I have come to San Antonio, where there are bushes of the graceful oleander.
And, as in a dream, I wonder if this is the very spot where that dreadful bloodshed took place in years gone by.
You do not see Chang Hsun, Hsu Yuan, and Nan Chiyun (David Crockett, Bowie, and Bonham)
But their fame, like the blossom's fragrance, is still in the air.
The custom of the West does not necessarily condemn surrender.
Why? We have never heard of a commander destroyed,
But here in the state of Texas, we see one (Travis).
In spirit there is not a distinction between East and West.
You need not wonder, then, if I drink a toast to your memory!
I have brought a well-polished stone from Japan,
And commemorate your heroic deeds with this humble inscription.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Although Nixon loved foreign policy most of all, he wanted to spend 1958 concentrating on the upcoming midterm elections and also looking ahead to 1960 and running for president. So in January, he turned down a State Department offer to make a goodwill trip to South America. He thought it wouldn't be that interesting and it would take time away from his domestic plans. As it turned out, it was the most exciting and almost the deadliest overseas trip he ever made.

The State Department and John Foster Dulles finally jawboned the vice president into spending 17 days in South America in May. It was purely a goodwill visit to eight different countries, with no serious items of discussion or diplomacy with South American leaders and the biggest goal was to attend the inauguration of new Argentine president Arturo Frondizi. Nixon was cautioned by CIA officials about the possibility of anti-American protesters or sentiment during the trip.

Nixon got through Colombia, Ecuador, Bolivia, and Paraguay without incident and friendly crowds waving to him. In Uruguay, a few students heckled him. The trip to Argentina and the inauguration of President Frondizi was also blessedly trouble-free. Only when he headed to Peru did things start to take a turn for the worse. He touched down in Lima and was treated to a luxurious luncheon from President Manuel Prado and his ministers, served on solid gold plates. Nixon noticed the widespread poverty and slums in Lima and felt that this was in poor taste. He felt an increased sense of foreboding as menacing demonstrators lined the streets.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In fact he was prepared to cancel his planned visit to the University of San Marcos, founded more than 400 years ago and the oldest university in the Western Hemisphere as it was reported that communist agitators were whipping students into a frenzy of anti-US hatred. No Peruvian official would outright tell Nixon not to go, but many of them hinted that it would be a very bad idea indeed. US ambassador Theodore Achilles told him that it was entirely his decision, but it might be bad PR to not go.

After a sleepless night, he finally went to the university, accompanied by a translator and one Secret Service agent, Jack Sherwood. A huge, loud mob of students was out front. One of them was heard to remark "El gringo tiene cojones" (the Yankee has balls) but most had no such respect. Spit, pebbles, and then rocks started flying. Jack Sherwood's front tooth was chipped by a stone and the party decided to slowly make their way to the waiting limousine. They headed off as Nixon yelled back defiantly "You're all cowards. That's what you are! You're afraid of the truth! You're the worst kind of cowards!"

On May 13, the party arrived at the airport in Caracas where a huge crowd was out front screaming obscenities. Heading down the aircraft steps, Nixon took Pat's arm and led her down the red carpet to the waiting terminal. An army band played "The Star Spangled Banner" while the Nixons paused to listen. The crowd booed and heckled through the US and Venezuelan national anthems. It would get worse. Inside the terminal, another huge crowd filling the balconies started spitting en masse. Loogies rained down on Nixon's blue suit and Pat's red dress.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The only escape would be to run for it, but no way was Nixon going to give them the satisfaction of that. The vice presidential couple instead simply walked through the rain of spit and shouting, screaming people until they got to their waiting ride at the other end of the terminal, acting as if nothing was happening. It must have taken a superhuman level of control for the two of them to endure this without flinching. Neither Nixon or Pat were happy about it, in fact both were absolutely apoplectic. As he wrote later in Six Crisis, "One must experience the sensation to know why spitting in a person's face is the most infuriating insult ever conceived by man."

Entering a fleet of limousines, apparently rented from a funeral parlor, the Nixons headed to downtown Caracas where an even worse mob lay in wait. Waving swastikas posters depicting Nixon as a vampire, large crowds of protestors tried to bum rush the motorcade to the chorus of "¡Muerte a Nixon!" They attacked the cars with rocks, lead pipes, clubs, and bare fists. A large rock hit the windshield, spraying everyone in the Nixons' limo with glass shards. The Venezuelan foreign minister was hit in the eye and began to bleed copiously. Vernon Walters, Nixon's translator, also received a nasty cut to the face. The Venezuelan motorcycle police escorting the motorcade disappeared.

With the cops gone, the mob seized the car bumpers and began shaking them. Nixon began wondering if this was the end. His two Secret Service agents drew their weapons and prepared to shoot at the crowd. One remarked "If we're gonna die, we ought to at least take a couple of those SOBs down with us." Nixon looked ashen as he waved to the agents and told them not to do it. Remaining cool and collected, he said "Don't shoot unless I tell you to." He was smart enough to realize that if the Secret Service fired into the crowd, they would go berserk and just kill everyone.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In the other limos, things were almost as bad. All the way back in car number nine, Rose Mary Woods was hit by flying glass and left choking on tear gas. In car number two, Pat was under assault from pounding and missiles being thrown. Her escort, Major Don Hughes, recalled "The mobs were coming at us. I can still see the wild hatred on their faces. I saw this rock getting slung, getting bigger and bigger as it came at us, finally smashing into the glass. The Venezuelan foreign minister's wife was sobbing in fear but Pat was as cool and calm as any man I ever saw under fire. She tapped her hostess on the shoulder and kept saying quietly 'Don't worry, it's gonna be alright. We'll be ok.'

Somehow, the party was miraculously saved by the arrival of the press truck, which bulldozed through the mob. The limos followed the truck to safety. It had been a mere 12 minutes of terror but it felt more like 12 years. The motorcycle cops reappeared and escorted Nixon to his planned speaking engagement, a wreath-laying ceremony at the Panteon Plaza. He decided instead it might be better to go to the US Embassy instead. As it turned out, Nixon's sixth sense was right. There was yet another mob waiting at the plaza, this one carrying knives and Molotov cocktails. If Nixon had gone there, it would have been the end of him for sure.

Safe in the US embassy, the leaders of the Venezuelan government apologized. Nixon was slow to accept them in and when he did, he laid into them for being this irresponsible with security during a state visit by a foreign leader. According to Don Hughes, "They didn't try to offer any excuses for what happened and they just took it like a couple of beaten puppies." Publicly, Nixon was more diplomatic. He said it was disgusting that the mob would tear down their own country's flag and hoped that US-Venezuelan relations would remain positive, and he had no more to say on the whole episode.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Meanwhile, back home, Eisenhower overreacted a little. Hearing the reports over the wire of what was going on in Caracas, he prepared to dispatch the Marines and the 101st Airborne in what was called "Operation Poor Richard" to save the vice president if need be. It was being reported throughout Latin America as an armed invasion by the gringo imperialists. Nixon did not like this gesture one bit especially as the White House hadn't asked him first. As it later turned out, the radio and TV frequencies in Venezuela had been all jammed as sabotage by the leaders of a would-be coup attempt, so Ike's precautionary measures went too far.

But Nixon's bravery in the face of near-death significantly elevated his standing at home and when he got back to Washington DC, he received a hero's welcome. He and Pat were being congratulated and receiving handshakes for weeks afterward. For two months, he was the most popular man in America and being called the 35th president of the United States beyond a reasonable doubt. At water coolers around the country, everyone was saying "Had you heard the news? Jack Kennedy wants equal time in Venezuela."

posts.com:
The Fugitive Slave Act and the Compromise of 1850 had aggravated sectional tensions in the country. At the Whig National Convention in Baltimore in June 1852, incumbent president Millard Fillmore was defeated for the nomination when the party turned to their tried-and-true strategy of nominating a war hero in Mexican War victor Winfield Scott. The Democrats however also nominated a Mexican War officer, albeit of a lesser stature, in New Hampshire's Franklin Pierce.

As with the 1848 presidential campaign, this election was a dull one without significant issues at stake and it inevitably turned into a personality contest. Whigs proclaimed Winfield Scott "a hero of many a well-fought battle" while calling Pierce "a hero of many a well-fought bottle", a reference to allegations that Pierce, while serving in Mexico, had fallen off a horse while drunk. Democrats declared "We Polk-ed 'em in '44, we'll Pierce 'em in '52!"

Pierce won the election on November 2 in an overwhelming rout with 254 electoral votes against Scott's 42 (including new state California, which gave its 4 electoral votes to Pierce). However he only got 50% of the popular vote due to the presence of several third parties including the Free Soil ticket and Know-Nothing Party. Not until 1932 would a Democrat presidential candidate win an election with this big a margin of electoral college victory. Winfield Scott only won four states, all in safe Whig territory. A friend remarked that the old general was "not used to running." A few hundred men voted for Daniel Webster in protest, although he had died a few weeks before Election Day. Voter turnout and enthusiasm in this election was the smallest since 1836.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The Whig Party breathed its last with the 1852 election. They had never developed a consistent platform, won only two presidential elections, both with war heroes who didn't live to finish their term, and finally choked to death on the Fugitive Slave Act. But the two party system would persist and many Whig planks would be taken up by the newly emergent Republican Party.

>Franklin Pierce was a handsome, charismatic man but he was no leader and his personal life was marred by tragedy. His wife Jane, an intensely pious and slightly unstable woman, had dreaded the idea of him running for president. Their 13 year old son Benny was killed in a train accident in Washington DC a few days before the inauguration, which a devastated Jane took as a symbol of the Almighty's displeasure at her husband being president. She remained withdrawn and in mourning for the rest of her life, having little involvement in White House social events.

>Although a New Englander, Pierce was surrounded by aggressive Southern Democrats who sought more land for slavery in the Caribbean when it became clear that the Mexican cession, largely desert, would never be suitable for plantation agriculture. Filibusters, private adventurers, made several unsuccessful attempts to take over parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. The administration also tried to buy Cuba from Spain but was rebuffed. A group of filibusters, including the sons of several prominent Southern families, tried to invade the island in 1854 but were quickly apprehended by Spanish authorities and shot for piracy. An angry mob retaliated by ransacking the Spanish consulate in New Orleans.

>The most famous filibuster was William Walker, who invaded northwestern Mexico in 1853 and was foiled by local authorities. He tried to invade Central America repeatedly and declared himself president of Nicaragua, ousted, sent back to the US, and charged with violating the Neutrality Act but twice, in San Francisco and NYC, a friendly jury acquitted him. Walker tried one last invasion of Honduras in 1860 and was caught by British authorities, who turned him over to the Honduran government. Walker was charged with piracy and shot.

This created two new territories and left their inhabitants the job of choosing to have legal slavery or not, effectively removing the ancient Missouri Compromise. I think a reason is a change in inheritance strategies and a crisis of nature vs modern world.

If you look what it takes to rear children now, its enormously far more bearing than it was in the past, cost wise. Whilst sure, we have become richer, and governments try to alleviate problems, most of those problems come from wealth and the governments own impositions. So the government is not really helping in as much as it isn't burdening as much (some) people with children. And wealth meant that there is an increase cost of living and an increase societal expectation of what wealth is demanded.

To raise a child back lets say 150 years ago, you needed to simply feed him and get at most 1-2 pairs of clothes for him, often mending and enlarging those clothes yourself. The biggest expense was probably a textbook. And you could probably have him pay for itself at 12 already if you sent him to work (doesn't have to be a mine but even apprenticeships). This already substantially lowers the cost of having children. And finally, by 16-18 he was almost grown up and could be expected to find his own career and go on. And that was it. You didnt need a bunch of expenditures, you could literally put a baby in a closet with a blanket. And if you had an extended family near you (which most people had to some degree back then), they could rise and share in the burden of rearing.

Nowadays it is far more expensive. You have to buy multiple clothes, textbooks, expensive food even, cosmetics, toys, time etc.. You cant make children work and even when you can, it is a massive social stigma a la too broke or child slavers. And the rearing time is much much longer. Now if you want your child to be even mildly successful (statistically) they have to go to college. minimum. And there are additional costs to this. You might be forced to pay for an extremely expensive education (1/7)

And that's is without the aid of an extended family to support you in most cases. But why is this? This leads to 2 different rearing strategies then from now. Back then, quantity was far more crucial.
